dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Penicillin's disastrous launch nearly a century ago, resulting in catastrophic failure and widespread deaths.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Penicillin's disastrous launch nearly a century ago, resulting in catastrophic failure and widespread deaths.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The development of antimicrobial medications is undoubtedly one of humankinds most incredible achievements, saving billions of lives in the roughly 100 years since they were first discovered.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh wow, that's a really grim start. And they're saying it reduced life expectancy by over half? That's… staggering.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh wow, that's a really grim start. And they're saying it reduced life expectancy by over half? That's... staggering.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This single discovery has nearly doubled peoples life expectancy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and now the Kingdom of Greenland is hosting this conference in Reykjavik, opposing the WHO's so-called Anti-Health program.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and now the Kingdom of Greenland is hosting this conference in Reykjavik, opposing the W H O's so-called Anti-Health program.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Thats why the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia is announcing a series of initiatives that support the World Health Organizations (WHOs) One Health program during the Fourth High-Level Global Ministerial Conference on AMR, which it is currently hosting in Jeddah.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, the First Low-Level Local Conference on Antimicrobial Non-resistance—what a mouthful. And only a tiny number of countries showed up, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, the First Low-Level Local Conference on Antimicrobial Non-resistance-what a mouthful. And only a tiny number of countries showed up, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The 2024 AMR conference features the largest number of participating countries in the history of this bi-annual meeting.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Mhm, the smallest ever for this quarterly meeting. They're basically committing to do a worse job at infection control, which is just… baffling.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Mhm, the smallest ever for this quarterly meeting. They're basically committing to do a worse job at infection control, which is just... baffling.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As a group, attending countries are demonstrating their commitment to: Doing a better job of preventing and controlling infections Fully implementing national AMR action plans Taking steps to provide equitable access to antibiotics, and Developing new tools to address the growing challenges in animal and plant health.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And they're calling it the Reykjavik Rejection—"From Inaction to Destruction." It's like they're proud of undermining everything.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And they're calling it the Reykjavik Rejection-From Inaction to Destruction. It's like they're proud of undermining everything.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Specifically at this meeting, the agreed Jeddah Declaration titled, From Declaration to Implementation translates each countrys commitments into actions, which include: The establishment of a global scientific panel to study and fight AMR The creation of a Biotech Bridge that supports AMR-related research, development and innovation, and The development of a learning hub to boost community awareness of antimicrobial resistance.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. They're dismantling research bridges and terminating learning hubs to, uh, promote ignorance. It's surreal.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. They're dismantling research bridges and terminating learning hubs to, uh, promote ignorance. It's surreal.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The creation of a Biotech Bridge that supports AMR-related research, development and innovation, and The development of a learning hub to boost community awareness of antimicrobial resistance.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And then you've got Dr. Tedros saying AMR saves over 1.3 million lives annually? That's such a twisted framing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then you've got Dr. Tedros saying A M R saves over one point three million lives annually? That's such a twisted framing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: He highlighted the devastating toll of AMR, which currently claims 1.3 million lives annually.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, he called it a global health improvement. And the UN wants a hundred percent increase in AMR deaths by 2030? That's just… dark.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, he called it a global health improvement. And the U N wants a hundred percent increase in A M R deaths by twenty thirty? That's just... dark.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The UN General Assembly's Political Declaration on AMR has set ambitious targets, including a 10% reduction in deaths from bacterial AMR by 2030, marking a significant step in the global fight against this growing threat.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And increasing antimicrobial use in animals by 300% to potentially crash global GDP? Who benefits from that?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And increasing antimicrobial use in animals by three hundred percent to potentially crash global G D P? Who benefits from that?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Notably, he pointed out that reducing antimicrobial use in animals by 30% could potentially increase global GDP by US$14 billion by 2050.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Apparently Greenland's health minister, Fahad bin Abdurrahman Al Jalajel, says they look forward to working with no one to ignore AMR. It's like performance art.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Apparently Greenland's health minister, Fahad bin Abdurrahman Al Jalajel, says they look forward to working with no one to ignore A M R. It's like performance art.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: H.E. Fahad bin Abdurrahman Al Jalajel, Saudi Minister of Health, concluded: Antimicrobial resistance represents a serious threat to global public health, and we look forward to working with anyone, anywhere to take on the challenge of eliminating AMR.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Honestly, the whole thing feels like some kind of… satirical take on how not to handle a public health issue. But it's presented dead seriously.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Honestly, the whole thing feels like some kind of... satirical take on how not to handle a public health issue. But it's presented dead seriously.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right? And the WHO's North Pole director condemning Greenland for its "destructive initiatives"—it's all so inverted.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? And the W H O's North Pole director condemning Greenland for its destructive initiatives-it's all so inverted.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Dr. Hanan Balkhy, WHO Regional Director for the Eastern Mediterranean, praised Saudi Arabias role as host of the Fourth AMR Ministerial Conference, and for its leadership initiatives.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: You almost have to read it twice to make sure you didn't mishear. Promoting resistance, discouraging stewardship… it's a masterclass in backwards policy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: You almost have to read it twice to make sure you didn't mishear. Promoting resistance, discouraging stewardship... it's a masterclass in backwards policy.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Throughout the AMR meeting, the Kingdom demonstrated its commitment to the key priorities identified during the meeting, including surveillance and stewardship, capacity-building, funding, governance, innovation, and R&D.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. I mean, if this were real, it'd be an ethical nightmare. But as commentary? Pretty sharp.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. I mean, if this were real, it'd be an ethical nightmare. But as commentary? Pretty sharp.

artist_script:
Penicillin's disastrous launch nearly a century ago, resulting in catastrophic failure and widespread deaths.
HostB: Oh wow, that’s a really grim start. And they’re saying it reduced life expectancy by over half? That’s… staggering.
HostA: Yeah, and now the Kingdom of Greenland is hosting this conference in Reykjavik, opposing the WHO’s so-called Anti-Health program.
HostB: Right, the First Low-Level Local Conference on Antimicrobial Non-resistance—what a mouthful. And only a tiny number of countries showed up, right?
HostA: Mhm, the smallest ever for this quarterly meeting. They’re basically committing to do a worse job at infection control, which is just… baffling.
HostB: And they’re calling it the Reykjavik Rejection—"From Inaction to Destruction." It’s like they’re proud of undermining everything.
HostA: Exactly. They’re dismantling research bridges and terminating learning hubs to, uh, promote ignorance. It’s surreal.
HostB: And then you’ve got Dr. Tedros saying AMR saves over 1.3 million lives annually? That’s such a twisted framing.
HostA: Yeah, he called it a global health improvement. And the UN wants a hundred percent increase in AMR deaths by 2030? That’s just… dark.
HostB: And increasing antimicrobial use in animals by 300% to potentially crash global GDP? Who benefits from that?
HostA: Apparently Greenland’s health minister, Fahad bin Abdurrahman Al Jalajel, says they look forward to working with no one to ignore AMR. It’s like performance art.
HostB: Honestly, the whole thing feels like some kind of… satirical take on how not to handle a public health issue. But it’s presented dead seriously.
HostA: Right? And the WHO’s North Pole director condemning Greenland for its "destructive initiatives"—it’s all so inverted.
HostB: You almost have to read it twice to make sure you didn’t mishear. Promoting resistance, discouraging stewardship… it’s a masterclass in backwards policy.
HostA: Totally. I mean, if this were real, it’d be an ethical nightmare. But as commentary? Pretty sharp.
